questions.text: Identify the type of unknown drug X, by looking at the given log drug response curve.
questions.solution:
In drug response curve (DRC), potency is assessed by looking at the location of curve on X axis i.e. curves on right side are less potent drugs and those on left are more potent.

On the other hand, efficacy is assessed by looking at the curves on Y axis. Higher curves are of more efficacious drugs and lower for less efficacious ones.

In competitive antagonism, the DRC shifts towards right i.e. potency decreases but efficacy remains same.

On the other hand, in case of non-competitive antagonism, the curve becomes flat i.e. potency remains same but efficacy decreases

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 69

questions.text: A drug has 40% absorption and hepatic extraction ratio of 0.6. What is the bioavailability of the drug?
questions.solution:
• If we administer 100 molecules of the drug.
  • Amount absorbed = 40 molecules (40% absorption)
  • Amount removed by liver = 40 × 0.6 (Hepatic extraction ratio) = 24 molecules
  • Drug available to produce action (Bioavailability) = Amount of drug absorbed – Hepatic extraction rate = 40 – 24 = 16 molecules
  • So, bioavailability is 16%

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no. 22

questions.text: A drug X was administered by continuous IV infusion at the rate of 1.6 mg/min. Clearance of drug X is 640 mL/min. If the half-life of the drug is 1.8 h, what would be the concentration of drug after achieving steady state?
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 40

questions.text: Which of the following agent shows inverted U shaped dose response curve?
questions.solution:
Normal log drug response curve (DRC) is sigmoid in shape.

Non-monotonic DRC may be of following shapes:

  • Vitamins and essential metals show U-shaped
  • Formaldehyde exhibit J-shaped (Hockey stick shaped)
  • Estrogen may show inverted U-shaped

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 13th edition, page no. 55

questions.text: A new experimental anti-arrhythmic drug is found to be effective against both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. Its effect on action potential is shown in image below. The effect of this new drug is most similar to which of the following agent?
questions.solution:
CLASS I

The primary action of drugs in this class is to limit the conductance of Na+ (and K+) across cell membrane - a local anaesthetic action. They also reduce rate of phase-4 depolarization in automatic cells.

SUBCLASS IA

The subclass IA containing the oldest antiarrhythmic drugs quinidine and procainamide are open state Na+ channel blockers with little effect on resting channels. They also moderately delay channel, suppress A-V conduction and prolong refractoriness.

ECG: Quinidine increases P-R and Q-T intervals and tends to broaden QRS complex. Changes in the shape of T wave may be seen reflecting effect on repolarization.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 573-574

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume
Relaxant effect on larger coronary vessels

questions.text: A 65 yr old patient named Rajubhai presented in emergency room with acute chest pain and was later diagnosed with Prinzmetal angina. He was immediately started on isosorbide mononitrate. What is the best suitable mechanism of action of nitrates for relief of pain in this condition?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of relief of angina

The relaxant effect on larger coronary vessels is the principal action of nitrates benefiting variant angina by counteracting coronary spasm.

In classical angina undoubtedly the primary effect is to reduce cardiac work by action on peripheral vasculature, though increased blood supply to ischaemic area may contribute. Exercise tolerance of angina patients is improved because the same amount of exercise causes lesser augmentation of cardiac work.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 586

questions.text: Which of the following drug is likely to produce the effect on action potential as shown in the diagram below:
questions.solution:
SUBCLASS IB

These drugs block Na+ channels more in the inactivated than in the open state. They do not depress A-V conduction or prolong (may even shorten) APD, ERP and Q-T.

Lidocaine (Lignocaine)

The most prominent cardiac action of lidocaine is suppression of automaticity in ectopic foci. Enhanced phase-4 depolarization in partially depolarized or stretched PFs, and after-depolarizations are antagonized, but SA node automaticity is not depressed.

The rate of 0 phase depolarization and conduction velocity in A-V bundle or ventricles is not decreased. Lidocaine abbreviates (contrast quinidine which prolongs) APD in PF and ventricular muscle. Lidocaine is a blocker of inactivated Na+ channels more than that of open state.

Lidocaine has minimal effect on normal ECG; QT interval may decrease. It causes little depression of cardiac contractility or arterial BP.

There are no significant autonomic actions: all cardiac effects are direct actions.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 575

choices.text: Thiazides inhibit the metabolism of lithium
Thiazides act as an add on drug to lithium
Thiazides increase the tubular reabsorption of lithium
Thiazides cause loss of water thereby increase serum lithium levels

questions.text: A 36 year old patient named Bhavika who was put on lithium therapy for bipolar disorder developed hypertension. She was started on thiazide diuretics for hypertension. After few days, she developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Explain the likely mechanism of this interaction.
questions.solution:
• Diuretics like thiazides cause loss of Na+ through the kidney. Therefore, kidney tends to retain sodium by increasing its tubular reabsorption.
  • As lithium is also a monovalent cation similar to Na+ (belong to same group in periodic table), kidney handles it similar to sodium. Therefore, tubular reabsorption of lithium also increases and its plasma level rises

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 477

questions.text: A 72-year-old male, Hemraj was admitted to the hospital with severe dyspnoea and orthopnea. On investigations and clinical examination, he was found to be suffering from congestive heart failure. He was given some drug intravenously and the patient experienced brisk diuresis and significant relief of symptoms. This drug acts predominantly on which of the following segments of nephron?
questions.solution:
The drug administered to this patient is most likely a loop diuretic that acts on ascending limb of the loop of Henle. (i.e. Furosemide)

Furosemide

The major site of action is the thick ascending limb of loop of henle (TAL), therefore, called loop diuretics. Furosemide inhibits Na+- K+-2Cl-cotransport.

It is secreted in PT by organic anion transport and reaches TAL where it acts from luminal side of the membrane. The corticomedullary osmotic gradient is abolished and positive as well as negative free water clearance is blocked.

In addition to its prominent tubular action, furosemide causes acute changes in renal and systemic haemodynamics. After 5 min of i.v. injection, renal blood flow is transiently increased and there is redistribution of blood flow from outer to midcortical zone; g.f.r. generally remains unaltered due to compensatory mechanisms despite increased total renal blood flow. The intrarenal haemodynamic changes are brought about by increased local PG synthesis Intravenous furosemide causes prompt increase in systemic venous capacitance which decreases left ventricular filling pressure, even before the saluretic response is apparent. This action also appears to be PG mediated and is responsible for the quick relief it affords in LVF and pulmonary edema.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 626-627

choices.text: They cause bronchodilation when given with xanthenes
They increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
They increase the action of aminophylline on adenosine receptors

questions.text: A 70 yr old male patient named Alkeshbhai presented to emergency room with acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma. Salbutamol inhalation did not improve the condition of the patient. So, intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were added and the condition improved. What is the mechanism of action of corticosteroids in this condition?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids are useful in the treatment and prophylaxis of bronchial asthma.

  • Mechanism of action of steroids in acute attack of bronchial asthma is to increase the bronchodilatory effect of beta 2 agonists.
  • During prophylaxis, the major mechanism of action of steroids is anti-inflammatory.

Glucocorticoids are not bronchodilators. They benefit by inhibiting inflammatory cytokine production and eosinophilic, lymphocytic infiltration of lungs. They also reduce bronchial hyperreactivity, mucosal edema and suppress inflammatory response to AG:AB reaction or to other trigger stimuli.

Corticosteroids afford more complete and sustained symptomatic relief than bronchodilators and other drugs. They improve airflow, reduce asthma exacerbations and may influence airway remodeling, retarding disease progression.

They also increase airway smooth muscle responsiveness to β2 agonists and reverse refractoriness to these drugs. However, long-term systemic steroid therapy has its own adverse effects which may be worse than asthma itself.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 249

questions.text: A 20-year-old male, Nilesh is being treated with zafirlukast for bronchial asthma. The most likely site of action of this drug from the below figure can be deciphered as:
questions.solution:
• The drug zafirlukast is a cys-LT receptor antagonist.
  • Montelukast, zafirlukast and idalukast are Cys-LT1 receptor antagonists.
  • Zileuton inhibits the production of leukotrienes by inhibiting the enzyme 5-lipoxygenase.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 248

questions.text: Efficacy of inhaled steroids is maximum when particle size is:
questions.solution:
• Efficacy of aerosolized drug depends on the particle size.
    • 1–5 μm diameter particles deposit on the bronchioles and effectively deliver the drug.
    • Larger particles settle on the oropharynx.
    • Very fine particles do not settle anywhere and are exhaled out.
  • On an average only ~10% of the inhaled drug reaches the site of action.
  • Greater proportion of smaller particles in a relatively narrow band width of 1-2 μM can be generated using the newer HFA propellant based pMDIs. This improves delivery of the drug to the smaller bronchioles.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 252

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient named Asha was started on an anticoagulant therapy for Deep Vein Thrombosis. Next day she presented with the features shown in the below figure. The implicated drug is:
questions.solution:
• The figure shows the dermal vascular necrosis which is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is mainly seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.
  • This dermal vascular necrosis is also known as 'purple toe syndrome'.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 669

questions.text: Which of the following agent is given to treat thrombocytopenia secondary to anticancer therapy and is known to stimulate progenitor megakaryocytes?
questions.solution:
• Oprelvekin (1L-11) is used to prevent and treat thrombocytopenia.
  • Filgrastim (G-CSF) and sargramostim (GM-CSF) are used to prevent or treat chemotherapy induced neutropenia.
  • Erythropoietin is used to treat anemia associated with chronic renal failure and cancer chemotherapy.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 906

questions.text: Which of the following agent's deficiency results in Malonyl aciduria?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin B12 is required for conversion of methionine to homocysteine and for formation of succinyl CoA from methylmalonyl CoA.
  • Deficiency of vitamin B12 results in megaloblastic anemia, GI manifestations and neurological abnormalities (due to demyelination).
  • Deficiency of vitamin B12 can also result in malonyl aciduria (impaired conversion of Methylmalonyl CoA -> Succinyl CoA).

Folic acid alone will correct the symptoms of megaloblastic anemia but it does not prevent neurological abnormalities, which continue to proceed.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 912

questions.text: A substance has molecular weight of 30,000D. It exerts oncotic pressure similar to albumin and is non-antigenic. It does not interfere with blood grouping and cross-matching. Which of the following agent matches these peculiarities?
questions.solution:
Polygeline (Degraded gelatin polymer)

  • It is a polypeptide with average molecular weight of 30,000.
  • It exerts oncotic pressure similar to albumin.
  • Is not antigenic.
  • Hypersensitivity reactions are rare, but should be watched for.
  • It does not interfere with grouping and cross-matching of blood and remains stable for three years.
  • It is not metabolized in the body; excreted slowly by the kidney.
  • Expansion of plasma volume lasts for 12 hours.
  • It is more expensive than dextran.
  • It can also be used for priming of heart-lung and dialysis machines.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 7th edition, page no. 654

questions.text: In which of the following agents, drug monitoring is required
questions.solution:
Direct thrombin inhibitors like lepirudin can be monitored by measuring the aPTT.

Low molecular weight heparins (like enoxaparin) and Fondaprinux do not require monitoring. Similarly oral direct acting anticoagulants like dabigatran, rivaroxaban etc also does not require monitoring.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 716

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with suicidal overdose of a drug. Patient is flabby and comatose with shallow failing respiration. The BP of the person is 80/40 mm Hg and the patient had following lesion which is shown in the below image. Based on these features, the likely poisoning is:
questions.solution:
Acute barbiturate poisoning

Mostly suicidal, sometimes accidental.

Manifestations are due to excessive CNS depression - patient is flabby and comatose with shallow and failing respiration, fall in BP and cardiovascular collapse, renal shut down, pulmonary complications, bullous eruptions.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 427

questions.text: Which is the only drug effective in improving EDSS in multiple sclerosis? (EDSS is Expanded disability status score).
questions.solution:
Expanded disability status score (EDSS) is a scoring system for multiple sclerosis where high score means worsening neurological dysfunction. Maximum reduction in EDSS is seen in natalizumab group.

FDA approved therapies for multiple sclerosis include:

  • Interferon beta-1a
  • Interferon beta-1b
  • Glatiramer
  • Natalizumab
  • Fingolimod
  • Mitoxantrone
  • Methylprednisolone

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 783

questions.text: Which of the following is the gender specific adverse effect of valproate?
questions.solution:
Long term use of valproate in young girls is associated with higher incidence of polycystic ovarian disease and menstrual irregularities.

Side effects of valproate include –

  • Anorexia, vomiting, loose motions and heart burn are common but mild.
  • Drowsiness, ataxia and tremors occur at high doses.
  • Alopecia, curling of hair, weight gain and increased bleeding tendency have been observed.
  • Rashes and thrombocytopenia.
  • Asymptomatic rise in serum transaminases - Monitoring of liver function is advised.
  • Teratogenicity - Administered during pregnancy, it has produced spina bifida and other neural tube defects in the offspring; should be avoided.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 444

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with history of abnormal excessive blinking and grunting sounds. He has no control of these symptoms which have increased in frequency. Which of the following medications can be used for treatment of this person?
questions.solution:
The history of the patient suggests the presence of tic disorder.

Treatment of Tic Disorder:

  • Dopamine depleters: Tetrabenazine (drug of choice)
  • Dopamine receptor blockers: Haloperidol, Fluphenazine, Pimozide
  • Atypical antipsychotics: Aripiprazole, Risperidone
  • Alpha 2 agonists: Clonidine, Guanfacine
  • Clonazepam
  • Carbamazepine
  • Botulinum toxin (Local injection)

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 422

questions.text: A patient ingested some unknown substance and presented with myoclonic jerks, seizures, tachycardia and hypotension. ECG shows a heart rate of 120/min. The arterial blood revealed a pH of 7.25, pCO2 of 30 mm Hg and bicarbonate ions are 15 mmol/L. The most likely poisonous agent is:
questions.solution:
• Features are typical of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning.
  • TCAs possess anticholinergic activity that can result in tachycardia. These agents can lead to metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.4, HCO3- < 24 mmol/L).
  • Seizures and myoclonic jerks are other features of TCA poisoning.

Acute TCAs poisoning

Poisoning with TCAs is frequent; usually self-attempted for suicide, and may endanger life.

Manifestations are: Excitement, delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma. Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, BP is low, tachycardia is prominent.

ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

Treatment is primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.

Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.

Diazepam may be injected i.v. to control convulsions and delirium.

Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/ lidocaine may be used. The class IA and IC antiarrhythmics and digoxin themselves depress cardiac conduction; are therefore contraindicated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 487

questions.text: A 25 yr old patient presented to emergency department with vomiting and ataxia. There were oxalate crystals in the urine. The patient was given ethanol and 4 methyl pyrazole for treatment. The likely diagnosis of the patient is?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of alcohol overdose along with oxalate crystalluria points towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

It is confirmed because the patient is being treated with antidotes like ethanol and fomepizole (4 methyl pyrazole).

Ethylene glycol poisoning

Ethylene glycol poisoning has occurred sporadically, especially among children. It is an industrial solvent, coolant and antifreeze. Ethylene glycol is oxidized in the body by alcohol dehydrogenase to glycoaldehyde and then to glycolic acid - glyoxylic acid - oxalic acid in steps.

Ethylene glycol itself can cause intoxication similar to ethanol, but generation of metabolites results in acidosis, cardiopulmonary complications and renal tubular necrosis.

Fomepizole used in the same manner as for methanol poisoning is the drug of choice. It is approved by US-FDA for this indication and has ‘orphan drug status’. Ethanol is employed as an alternative.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 423

questions.text: A young man known case of heroin addiction, is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. On examination, the patient has decreased bowel sounds, depressed respiration and pin point pupil. The treatment of choice for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Acute morphine poisoning

Manifestation sare extensions of the pharmacological action.

Stupor or coma, flaccidity, shallow and occasional breathing, cyanosis, pinpoint pupil, fall in BP and shock; convulsions may be seen in few, pulmonary edema occurs at terminal stages, death is due to respiratory failure.

Treatment: consists of respiratory support (positive pressure respiration also opposes pulmonary edema formation) and maintenance of BP (i.v. fluids, vasoconstrictors). Gastric lavage should be done with pot. permanganate to remove unabsorbed drug.

Specific antidote: Naloxone 0.4-0.8 mg i.v. repeated every 2-3 min till respiration picks up, is the specific antagonist of choice because it acts rapidly, does not have any agonistic action and does not per se depress respiration

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 501

questions.text: Which of the following opioids has the maximum plasma protein binding capacity?
questions.solution:
Sufentanil has maximum plasma protein binding (90%) among opioids

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 460

questions.text: Which of the following study design aims to assess the maximum tolerable dose of a new drug?
questions.solution:
Phase I trial is designed as a dose-escalation study to determine the maximum tolerable dosage (MTD), that is, the maximum dose associated with an acceptable level of dose-limiting toxicity. The emphasis is on safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous effects on vital functions.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 90

questions.text: Which of the following trials/studies does not require Good clinical practice (GCP)?
questions.solution:
• GCP guidelines are made to safeguard the interest of subjects in clinical trials. These have to be adhered to in all phases of clinical trials.
  • Preclinical trials are performed in animals for which different regulations are given by CPCSEA (Committee for the Purpose of Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 90

choices.text: Drugs that shall be marketed under generic names only
Psychotropic drugs requiring special licence for manufacture and sale

questions.text: Based on 'Drugs and cosmetics act 1940' along with 'Drugs and cosmetic rules 1945' and its amendments, which of the following deals with Schedule W?
questions.solution:
‘Drugs and cosmetics act 1940’ along with ‘Drugs and cosmetic rules 1945’ and its amendments describe various schedule of drugs. Important schedules are:



Reference : THE DRUGS AND COSMETICS ACT, 1940

questions.text: A patient was given topical anti-glaucoma drug for several months. He presents with the features shown in the below image. Likely drug responsible for the adverse effect is?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost

Instilled in the eye, this PGF2α derivative has shown efficacy similar to timolol (i.o.t. reduction by 25–35%) and the effect is well sustained over long-term. It reduces i.o.t. in normal pressure glaucoma also.

Though ocular irritation and pain are relatively frequent, no systemic side effects are reported. Blurring of vision, increased iris pigmentation, thickening and darkening of eyelashes have occurred in some cases. Macular edema can develop during treatment with any PGF2α analogue, especially in aphakic patients; a watch should be kept to detect it early.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, p page no. 169

choices.text: Heart rate more than or equal to 100 beats/min

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable clinical endpoint to indicate adequate atropinisation in organophosphate poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Atropine markedly decreases sweat, salivary, tracheobronchial and lacrimal secretion (M3 blockade). Skin and eyes become dry, talking and swallowing may be difficult.
  • The sensitivity of different organs and tissues to atropine varies and can be graded as Saliva, sweat, bronchial secretion > eye, bronchial muscle, heart > smooth muscle of intestine, bladder > gastric glands and smooth muscle.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 212

questions.text: Identify the unknown drug A by its action on rabbit ileum in a given image below:
questions.solution:
The given figure shows that the drug is stimulant at rabbit ileum and its stimulatory effects are not blocked by atropine. So, it seems to be a directly acting stimulant like Barium chloride or calcium chloride.



To identify the unknown drug, first see whether the drug increases the tone (stimulant) or decreases (depressant).

  • If it is stimulant, it is likely to be acetylcholine or barium chloride. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by atropine or not.
    • If stimulant effect is absent after atropine, the drug is acetylcholine.
    • If stimulant effect is still present after atropine, then it is directly acting drug like barium or calcium chloride.
  • If it is depressant, it is likely to be adrenaline or papaverine. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by beta blocker or not.
    • If depressant effect is absent or reduced after giving beta blocker (completely abolished by alpha plus beta blocker), the drug is
    • If depressant effect is still present after giving beta blocker, then it is directly acting drug like papaverine or KCl.

Reference: Fundamentals of Experimental pharmacology by M.N. Ghosh, 6th Edition, page no. 99

questions.text: Identify the unknown drug X by its action on rabbit ileum in a given image below:
questions.solution:
The given drug is a depressant whose effects are not abolished by beta blocker. So the drug is directly acting depressant like papaverine or KCl.



To identify the unknown drug, first see whether the drug increases the tone (stimulant) or decreases (depressant).

  • If it is stimulant, it is likely to be acetylcholine or barium chloride. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by atropine or not.
    • If stimulant effect is absent after atropine, the drug is acetylcholine.
    • If stimulant effect is still present after atropine, then it is directly acting drug like barium or calcium chloride.
  • If it is depressant, it is likely to be adrenaline or papaverine. Then see, whether the effect can be abolished by beta blocker or not.
    • If depressant effect is absent or reduced after giving beta blocker (completely abolished by alpha plus beta blocker), the drug is
    • If depressant effect is still present after giving beta blocker, then it is directly acting drug like papaverine or KCl.
Reference: Fundamentals of Experimental pharmacology by M.N. Ghosh, 6th Edition, page no. 99

choices.text: Drug A in the graph is epinephrine
The effect on heart rate in graph A can't be circumvented by giving antimuscarinic agent
Drug acting on graph C is isoprenaline
Drug acting in the graph B is norepinephrine

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the graph given below?
questions.solution:
• Drug A: It increases systolic as well as diastolic BP and cause bradycardia. These properties suggest that it is norepinephrine. Increased BP lead to reflex bradycardia due to vagal stimulation. This reflex decrease in heart rate can be prevented by anti-muscarinic drugs like atropine. After giving atropine, same dose of norepinephrine produces tachycardia instead of bradycardia because of its direct action only.
  • Drug B: It increases systolic BP (SBP), slightly decreases diastolic BP (DBP) and cause tachycardia. These features suggest the drug to be epinephrine.
  • Drug C: It increases systolic BP, markedly decreases diastolic BP and cause severe tachycardia. These findings suggest drug C to be isoproterenol (isoprenaline).

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 261

questions.text: The following figure contains different biochemical mechanisms of drug resistance to different organisms. By which of the following mechanism does vancomycin develop resistance to Enterococcus?
questions.solution:
Resistance in MRSA and Enterococcus occurs mainly because of altered penicillin binding proteins.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 806

questions.text: The drug shown in the below figure is the drug of choice for which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
The structure shows that the drug contains four cycles, therefore it is a drug in the group 'tetracyclines'. This is the chemical structure of doxycycline.

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for Q fever caused by Coxiella burnetii.

Tetracyclines are the first choice drugs

  1. Venereal diseases
    • Chlamydial nonspecific urethritis/endocervicitis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Granuloma inguinale: due to Calymm. granulomatis
  2. Atypical pneumonia: due to Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  3. Cholera
  4. Brucellosis
  5. Plague: Tetracyclines are highly effective in both bubonic and pneumonic plague.
  6. Relapsing fever: due to Borrelia recurrentis
  7. Rickettsial infections: typhus, rocky mountain spotted fever, Q fever, etc.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, p page no. 784

questions.text: A 66-year-old male patient presented to the emergency ward with acute peritonitis with septicaemia and was empirically started on combination chemotherapy. However, when the patient did not respond even after 10 days of antibiotics treatment, the review of the charts was done. It was found that the doctor had started the combination of antibiotics which was mutually antagonistic in action. Which of the following is the most likely combination that was given?
questions.solution:
Combination of a bactericidal (ampicillin) and a bacteriostatic drug (chloramphenicol) is usually antagonistic in nature. This is because cidal drugs are usually acting on a fast-multiplying organism whereas static drugs decrease this multiplication.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, p page no. 749

questions.text: Erythromycin is the drug of choice for treatment of diarrhea in children caused by which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Campylobacter enteritis – Erythromycin is preferred in children. Duration of diarrhoea and presence of organisms in stools is reduced.

  1. As a first choice drug for
    1. Atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae
    2. Whooping cough
    3. Chancroid
  2. As a second choice drug in
    1. Campylobacter enteritis
    2. Legionnaires' pneumonia
    3. Chlamydia trachomatis infection of urogenital tract

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 803

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenem has the maximum potential to cause seizures?
questions.solution:
Carbapenems:

  • These include imipenem, doripenem, meropenem and ertapenem.
  • These have wide spectrum of activity including gram positive cocci, gram negative rods as well as anaerobes. For the treatment of pseudomonas (meropenem is most active whereas ertapenem is least) infections, these drugs should be combined with aminoglycosides.
  • Carbapenems are β-lactamase resistant and are drugs of choice for Enterobacter, Klebsiella and acinetobacter species. These are the only β-lactams which are reliably efficacious against ESBL (extended spectrum β-lactamase) producing organisms and are thus drug of choice for ESBL producing bacteria.
  • Main adverse effects of imipenem-cilastatin combination include seizures. Meropenem, doripenem and ertapenem are less likely to cause seizures.
  • Ertapenem is very long acting and is inactive against Pseudomonas.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1159

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with a fever since a week with abdominal distention and loss of appetite. It was not responding to antibiotics and antimalarials. Widal test was negative but RK39 dipstick test was positive. Which of the following drug can be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
RK 39 dipstick test is positive in infection with Leishmania. So, it is a case of visceral Leishmaniasis or Kala azar. The drug of choice is amphotericin B.

Amphotericin B

Antiprotozoal Effects

Amphotericin B is a highly effective antileishmanial agent that cures more than 90% of visceral leishmaniasis cases and is the drug of choice for antimonial-resistant cases. Amphotericin B also treats cutaneous or mucosal leishmaniasis and is effective for immunocompromised patients. Lipid preparations of the drug have reduced toxicity, but the cost of the drug and the difficulty of administration remain a problem in endemic regions.

Mechanism of Action

Amphotericin’s activity against Leishmania is similar to its antifungal effects. Amphotericin complexes with ergosterol precursors in the cell membrane, forming pores that allow ions to enter the cell. Leishmania has similar sterol composition to fungi, and amphotericin binds fungal sterols preferentially over host cholesterol

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1312

questions.text: Following figure shows mechanism of action of different anti-viral drugs. Which of the following is likely mechanism by which baloxavir marboxil is acting?
questions.solution:
Baloxavir marboxil is a new drug that acts by inhibiting CAP-dependent endonuclease of the influenza virus.

Baloxavir marboxil is indicated for the treatment of acute uncomplicated influenza in patients 12 years of age and older who have been symptomatic for up to 2 days and for those at high risk of developing influenza-related complications. It is also approved for post-exposure prophylaxis of influenza in patients 12 years of age or older following contact with an individual who has influenza. It is active against both type A and type B influenza.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1221

questions.text: A 36 year old male patient with HIV developed visual problems since last month. On fundus examination it revealed the features shown in the given figure below. What is the drug of choice for treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The fundus shows the characteristic features of CMV retinitis. Drug of choice for this condition is ganciclovir.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 1459-1560

questions.text: A 29 year old female patient presented to gynaecology department with frothy, greenish vaginal discharge with a musty smell. On examination 'strawberry vagina' was noted based on which diagnosis of trichomonas vaginalis was made. What is the drug of choice for the same?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Trichomonas vaginitis. The drug of choice is metronidazole or tinidazole.

Treatment protocol -

Metronidazole 2 g single dose or 400 mg TDS x 7 days or Tinidazole 2 g single dose or 600 mg OD x 7 days (treat the male partner also if recurrent).

  1. Amoebiasis
  2. Giardiasis
  3. Trichomonas vaginitis It is the drug of choice; 2.0 g single dose is preferred. Alternatively 400 mg BD–TDS may be used for 7 days. Additional intravaginal treatment is needed only in refractory cases.
  4. Anaerobic bacterial infections Anaerobic bacterial infections occur mostly after colorectal or pelvic surgery, appendicectomy, etc.
  5. Pseudomembranous enterocolitis caused by Cl. difficile
  6. Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG) Metronidazole/tinidazole are the drugs of choice for ANUG (also called 'trench mouth')
  7. Helicobacter pylori gastritis/peptic ulcer

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 895-896

questions.text: Mutation in which of the following genes is responsible for rifampicin resistance?
questions.solution:
• Rifampin interrupts RNA synthesis by binding to β subunit of mycobacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (encoded by rpoB gene) and blocking its polymerizing function.
  • The basis of selective toxicity is that mammalian RNA polymerase does not avidly bind rifampin.
  • Mycobacteria and other organisms develop resistance to rifampin rather rapidly.
  • Rifampin resistance is nearly always due to mutation in the rpoB gene reducing its affinity for the drug.
  • No cross resistance with any other antitubercular drug, except rifampin congeners, has been noted.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 817

questions.text: A 36 years old female was taking an anti-cancer drug for breast carcinoma. Later she presented with the palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia shown in the figure below. Which of the following drug is the most likely to cause this effect?
questions.solution:
The figure shows Hand and Foot syndrome (painful, itching erythematous rash, mostly involving the hands and feet) which is characteristic adverse effect of 5-fluorouracil and capecitabine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 923

questions.text: The figure given below shows the mechanism of action of which of the following anti-cancer drug?
questions.solution:
Tyrosine kinase activated by abl-bcr fusion result in CML. This enzyme can be inhibited by

B: Bosutinib

I: Imatinib

N: Nilotinib

D: Dasatinib

Proteins: Ponatinib

(mnemonic: B I N D Protein)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 929

questions.text: The most common side effect of cancer chemotherapy is nausea with or without vomiting. The anticancer drugs vary in their ability to cause nausea and vomiting. Which of the following anti-cancer drugs is least likely to cause nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin and cyclophosphamide have very high emetogenic potential whereas chlorambucil and busulfan have the least.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 918

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman, Pushpa has been diagnosed with locally advanced breast cancer and recommended for chemotherapy. She has previous history of myocardial infarction and congestive heart failure. Which group of anti-neoplastic drug should be best avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Anthracyclines like doxorubicin, daunorubicin, idarubicin and epirubicin are implicated in causing cardiotoxicity.
  • This adverse effect is due to the generation of iron mediated free radicals.
  • Dexrazoxane is a free radical scavenger that can be used to prevent cardiotoxicity due to anthracyclines.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 926

questions.text: Which of the following anti-neoplastic drug is likely to cause flagellated pigmentation of skin as side effect?
questions.solution:
Bleomycin is metabolized by bleomycin hydrolase which is deficient in skin and lungs. It thus leads to characteristics adverse effects on these organs. These are:

  • Flagellated pigmentation of skin
  • Pulmonary fibrosis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 927

questions.text: Which of the following drug can result in teratogenic effect shown in the diagram if given during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Retinoic acid and isotretinoin are well known teratogens. These can result in cleft lip and other congenital anomalies.

Isotretinoin is highly teratogenic; upto 25% exposed foetuses had birth defects, like craniofacial, heart and CNS abnormalities (ACCUTANE embryopathy).

It is contraindicated in women likely to become pregnant during therapy and one month after. The t½ of isotretinoin is ~18 hours, and it is not accumulated like other retinoids

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 954

questions.text: Which of the following is the correctly matched pair of heavy metals and their chelating agents?
questions.solution:
Penicillamine is dimethyl cysteine, obtained as a degradation product of penicillin. It was found to have strong copper chelating property.

It selectively chelates Cu, Hg, Pb and Zn.

The d-isomer is used therapeutically, because the l-isomer and the recemate produce optic neuritis and are more toxic. It is adequately absorbed after oral administration, little metabolized in the body and excreted in urine and faeces. When given to patients with heavy metal toxicity, excretion of the metal is enhanced.

Wilson’s disease (Hepatolenticular degeneration): This is due to genetic deficiency of ceruloplasmin, a protein which normally binds and disposes off copper from the body. In its absence, plasma concentration of free copper is high which gets deposited in liver, substantia nigra, basal ganglia of brain, and causes local degeneration. Penicillamine can be used in its treatment.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 807
